content:
All six screenshots are of the Program Files\Mozilla Thunderbird folder. That's Thunderbird's installation folder and it only contains program files used by Thunderbird. Thunderbird's data is stored in a separate folder.

Go back to the root of that storage drive, then go to Users\<username>\AppData\Roaming\Thunderbird\Profiles inside which you will find your Thunderbird profile folder containing the Mail and ImapMail folders. For details about Thunderbird's data location, see Profiles - Where Thunderbird stores your messages and other user data

That AppData folder is hidden by default. To see it, you have to enable showing of hidden folders via File Explorer options. See https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/view-hidden-files-and-folders-in-windows-97fbc472-c603-9d90-91d0-1166d1d9f4b5 for details.
creator: stancestans

content: In the folder, look for two folders,Mail and Imapmail. If the account was POP, there will be account name and message folders in the Mail folder. If IMAP, that info will be in Imapmail folder.

content: Did you visit your provider's website and used the forgot password facility to change your password? That's the only way. You can't change your account's password via Thunderbird.
creator: stancestans

content:
What version of Thunderbird are you using ?

In 102.14.0, 'Write' is on the 'Mail Toolbar' along with GetMessages, Tgas, Menu icon, Global Search etc.

If you do not have any toolbars visible: Press the 'Alt' key on keyboard and it will show the 'Menu Bar' temporarilly. Then set it up as permanent: 'View' > 'Toolbars' > select 'Menu Bar'

re :now all task bar disappeared If you have the 'Menu Bar' enabled - File, Edit, View etc 'View' > 'Toolbars' > select 'Mail Toolbar'

This will get all your toolbars back. Do you now see 'Write' button?
creator: Toad-Hall
